posts.author: samurainostalgique
posts.content:
Hello,

I'm currently playing on a french RP PW called Baldur's Gate Nights. It's still a beta, but I'm quite enthusiastic about it.

I'm playing as a monk/fighter and planning to take rogue levels later on. However, the admin wants to modify the module's hak to make taunt a fighter class skill. I figure taunt would be tremendously useful for a low AB toon like this one, so I'm going to reroll the character to take it.

And so I would like some advice as to how to build him.
I've already thought about a build, and would like to know what ecbguilders think about it.

A few informations about the PW to better understand some of the choices I made, and the constraints of this build:

-This is a full epic level 40 PW with +6 items. It starts at level 6, but I'm already level 13, and will probably get back the xp I've got now.

-There are a few restrictions about multiclassing here: monks, paladins, clerics and druids can't multiclass with other base classes, but only with prestige classes (granted the prestige class doesn't require another base class). There is an exception for monks though: they can also multiclass into fighter and/or rogue. However, monk has to be the first class. You cannot start as a rogue at level 1 and become a monk. Also, you need to have at least 5 levels in each class.

-You can't buy scrolls or potions of invisibility, nor scrolls of true seeing, and lots of other scrolls for that matter, from npcs. Thus, stealth skills are very useful here. However, the admin plans to add a few mobs with true seeing.

-As said above, the fighter class is going to be modified to have taunt as a class skill

-All the classes that gained 2 skillpoints per level, such as fighter, have been modified to give 4 skill points instead.

-From a roleplaying point of view, PCs that have less than 10 in any given ability are considered to be extremely handicaped in that particular ability. For example, a PC with less than 10 intelligence would not even be able to make correct sentences, and would sound like the low intelligence PCs from the old fallout games. Since I don't want to roleplay such a handicap, I want to have at least 10 in every ability, even in charisma.

-I care more about PvM than PvP, though I may duel other PCs from time to time.

-Since the concept of this character is a master monk, I prefer to have at least 20 monk levels for the "perfect self" feat. I also want to fight unarmed.

-I know this build will have an xp penalty, but I'm willing to endure it. I care more about the end result than the time it takes me to achieve it.

- Though I've started as a human, I could also start over as an elf for the extra dexterity. But that's a difficult choice to make in a build with so many interesting class skills.

So, I've come up with this build:

I'm concerned though about the low AB and the lack of discipline and concentration (the admin plans to add mobs that taunt PCs). I've thought about abandonning either stealth or traps for a more dedicated meleer, maybe an elf to have a little more AB and AC, but these skills add so much that it's very difficult to part with either of them.

What do you think about it?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Samurai.

Afraid I'm not in a position to give a proper analysis atm, just a couple of things, if you don't mind?

How wedded are you to Human or Elf? Halfling could bring you some great results here - particularly if you're not too concerned with xp penalties.

Second, I can't recall the exact figures (I'll check them later, if no one else has come back to you), but I'm positive you don't need to take so many points in trapping skills to deal with and set all deadlies, if not epics. Equally, I reckon you're overpowered in Search. If we're lucky, with some astute pruning we should be able to get you a good wallop of Concentration or Listen (I wouldn't worry overmuch about Discipline in a build like this one).

Third (ok, so I lied about "a couple of things"), I'm sure we can increase the AB by some juggling - and we might well be able to get Epic Dodge in earlier to soothe some of your AC questions - again, afraid I've little time at the moment, but let me mull - unless one of the great and good comes along in the meantime.

Finally (and I'm assuming you want to employ the Expertise-Taunt trick with the build, hence the inclusion of the two Expertise feats, so I won't be questioning them), several of your feats will require a decent AB to work properly at later levels, which you don't really have at the moment - I'm thinking most particularly about the Disarm feats, but Called Shot comes to mind as well. And perhaps Toughness is vulnerable, too, if something else proves more helpful.

I do like the principle behind it, and I'm guessing it would only take a few tweaks to bump it up somewhat.

Sorry, have to go now. Be in touch later.

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Seems like Tyr's "Death Dealer" modified to your needs, which is fine. With the restrictions you have set upon yourself, can't get much more out of it anyway.

An AB of 39 is enough for a Monk's attack progression and a role-playing character in general. Plus, you have a high "Taunt" skill for tough opponents, right?

If you want Concentration or Discipline (first will be more useful given your high armour class) then you can reduce "Set Traps" to 6 (15) and UMD to 35 (35). That will give you 41 skill points which you can spend there instead. I doubt UMD more than 35 will be necessary in a medium-magic PW anyway.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Ha! I'll get back in my box and shut the lid now.

@Stagmeister 
Well I'm not exactly wedded to either human or elf, but since halfling monks only get 2d6 damage unarmed compared to medium size monks' 1d20, I'm thinking such a toon might have more problems dealing with sneak-immune ennemies, not to mention the inability to knockdown taller foes (though I reckon that with his low ab, he will have problems knocking them down later on anyway).

Which feats would you advise me to take instead of disarm and called shot? I've been considering replacing them myself for dodge and maybe some saving throw increasing feats. I don't think replacing toughness would be a good choice though. This character doesn't have that many hitpoints for a meleer.

@Valerfor
Reducing set traps to 6 (15), that would mean that I only get to set deadly traps, and only when not in combat. But I suppose I have to sacrifice something at some point. Perhaps skill mastery would be a better investment than crippling strike?

One alternative I've thought about is sacrificing epic skill focus: taunt to get one more great dexterity, allowing me to start with only 15 dexterity, dropping constitution to 10, and increasing intelligence to 16 for the skill points for concentration, but that might be too heavy of a price to pay for one more skill, especially since I would only have 43 points in taunt then, and I don't know yet how much will be needed. For now, I've been facing only low concentration mobs, but that might change when the module is completed.

I've tried searching for the build you're talking about, but I can't seem to find it.

In the end I'll probably do without discipline and concentration. As you and Stagmeister both pointed out, discipline isn't that great for this build given the high AC, epic dodge, and low strength. And if I ever have to duel a dedicated PC taunter, his skill is probably going to be too high for me to have reasonable chances to resist even with a maxxed concentration anyway.

I do need to rearrange my skill points a bit, as I have noticed that I have more points in set traps than needed for epic traps, but not enough disable traps to actually recover epic traps! I also forgot to take synergy bonuses from disable traps and set traps into account.

So in the end, his skills should look like that:

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Thing is, you are so "by the book" correct in your choices that i am hesitant to point out any changes and i will explain why...

Improved Disarm is "Ideal" for an unarmed character, since you take full advantage of the feat, in theory at least.
Called Shot is a good feat to use when IKD does not work (immunities or other) so that is good also.

Now if we knew more things about your PW then i could say with certainty that for example, your AB isn't good enough for this feat or the other, or that you don't need a measly +2 to your fortitude save. But as it is i can't do that because i know next to nothing about the enemies you are going to face. That's why i said that "By the Book" you are very correct in your choices, especially so if you like and use those combat feats, because having them only isn't enough...

I don't know how I came up with 323 skill points, but doing the maths again, I've found out that I actually have 353 skill points to spend!

So now comes another tough choice: going with a more balanced build, staying human and spending the 30 extra points to get spellcraft to 18(20) or going for a more offensive build, becoming elf, sacrificing 2 points of constitution, called shot, ignoring spellcraft completely, and lowering set traps a bit, becoming dependant on dexterity increasing items to set epic traps, all of that in order to gain 2 points of dexterity.

At the moment, human seems like the better choice to me, especially since I don't seem to have too much trouble hitting things for now, and called shots to the legs can sometimes be used to lower ennemy AC anyway, but I have yet to see the high level content on this PW.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
That's true, Samurai, but then, neither is 426 HP (although I can certainly see breaking the 400 point barrier can feel important). Given that you'll be doing a lot of trapping, I reckon you'd be better served by 12/12 STR/CON split. A lot will depend on your own play-style, but for me, in a melee build, anything less than 12 in STR unnerves me. Another thought might be to also drop WIS to 13 - I reckon your natural AC and Will save are good enough - and start with a DEX of 17, which would enable you either take an extra Great Dex (at the expense, I'd guess, of either Epic Prowess or the Taunt focus), or free up one of those Great Dex slots for something else. Just thoughts, feel free to ignore...

Oh, and this has very little bearing, I imagine, but I seem to recall Hip (also a skills demon - and particularly UMD) saying that a nett UMD of 33 is adequate for casting all scrolls without failure, and that any more is unnecessary as Monks will be wearing Monk gear anyway, so will be unlikely to require items requiring more.

Cheers

posts.author: samurainostalgique
posts.content:
Well the thing is, this build was made with some specific modifications in mind (mainly taunt as a fighter class skill), so it would have to be modified for vanilla NWN.

Basically, you'd have 3 choices:
1. Keeping the fighter levels and ditching taunt (and thus the epic skill focus and probably also the expertise feats)
2. Replacing the fighter levels by blackguard or paladin levels (the former comes with no xp penalty), giving up WS and EWS+ 2 pre-epic feats
3. Keeping the fighter levels, and cross-classing taunt; but obviously it will only be effective if you're facing mostly low concentration ennemies.

Also, without the rules of this specific PW, you'd want to start as a rogue of course, for more skillpoints. But since fighters, paladins and blackguards in vanilla NWN only gain 2 skillpoints per level, you'd still end up with exactly the same amount of skillpoints.

Maybe I'd also give him a 14 in wisdom instead of strength. It seems to me that it's difficult to have enough AC for duels with high AB characters such as clerics and weapon masters.
